subject: Catching RuntimeExceptions
msgSnippet: ... testing ... Not necessarily. If I have a public API, it may be worthwhile to try to interpret the dozens of RuntimeExceptions that my code may throw, since
messageBody:
On 2002-09-11 at 11:40 Chappell, Simon P wrote:

><snip>
>
>>My complaint is that you can have valid, thoroughly tested software
>>that complies to all your tests (JUnit-, integration- and acceptance
>>tests) and still have JTest complain about it.
>
>If Jtest is complaining, then is it REALLY valid and thoroughly tested
>code? I'm not trying to bait you, but if you have a automated code
testing
>tool (let's be generic here, so no-one thinks that I'm on the ParaSoft
>payroll :-) and it complains about your code then either the tool is
>defective or your code is sub-optimal.

Not necessarily.

If I have a public API, it may be worthwhile to try to interpret the
dozens of RuntimeExceptions that my code may throw, since this would
help my clients decipher the problem. In this case, it would be nice to
use something like JTest to discover all the RuntimeExceptions my
public API might throw.

If, however, we deal with code deep within our library that the outside
world doesn't use directly, and if we can be reasonably sure that, for
example, Class A never passes a null reference to Class B, then it
would likely be overkill to worry about what happens when Class B
receives a null reference. As Ron Jeffries would say, if you're the
only client, then simply don't pass null! (Loose paraphrase, there.)

>>Here is another way of putting it:
>>Personally I think that the 'exposure' of (mainly) NullPointers by
>>applying generated tests that put nonsense parameter values in
methods
>>does improve the quality of the product.
>
>Agreed. :-)

Well, it can identify issues, but I'm not sure that it improves
quality, since it may lead to a morass of duplication of the form

if (blah == null) {
throw new IllegalArgumentException("Blah was null.");
}

That hurts the internal quality of the product.

>>The motto 'Garbage in Garbage out' still applies in this case. As an
>
>Not agreed. GIGO is only for non-robust code. I think that "Garbage
In"
>should cause appropriate guard conditions to be triggered and an
>appropriate response to be generated NPE or IAE (your choice). For
>anything other than the most trivial of code, I do not want to ever
>contribute to "Garbage Out". As developers we usually have no control
over
>the many potential ways that our code could be used, but we do have
>control over how it responds.

Once again, a public API is different from code whose only client is
you. :)

<snip />
>This is the concept of "graceful degredation". A web browser is a very
>good example of this .... a lot of web pages have awful HTML and yet
most
>of them display acceptably, because the browser takes what it's given
and
>does the best it can with it. A browser cannot throw an exception, but
it
>can try to render what it's given. All software should do the best it
can
>with what it's given or when possible reject unacceptable inputs.

I hate this, because the browser just throws away parts of a page, and
it's not always easy to tell why that happened. It would be better, in
my opinion, if the browser at least complained to a log or something.
